ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT coevolution
ygData.msgSnippet: Peter, Thank you for the details.  Is there any chance you could release a version that lets the user scale the networks and observe the impact? That would be

Peter, 

Thank you for the details.  Is there any chance you could release =
a
version that lets the user scale the networks and observe the impact?
 Th=
at would be very interesting.  You mentioned that it does generally
work wi=
th some imperfections.

Another interesting thing about these substrates is=
 that they appear
to be highly recurrent.  Is that right?  The amount of re=
currence
suggests that the mechanisms for action are likely quite different=

than what we see for example in early generation regaular NEAT,
because th=
ese substrate networks must have ways of maintaining
equilibrium and self-s=
tabilizing cycling activation.

About the complexification,  I am sure ther=
e is some limit due to the
finite nature of the substrate, although it will=
 take a while to get
there.  However, of course, if you start with a bigger=
 substrate the
limit is greater.

By the way, I wonder if there is a memory=
 leak or something like that?
 I notice that after 100 generations or so th=
e simulation of the
robots on the screen slowed down a lot.  However, I do =
not see a
reason that it should slow down since the substrates are always t=
he
same size.  Why would they simulate slower in one generation than anothe=
r?

Finally, just out of curiosity, why is your version of NEAT protected
b=
ehind an NDA?  Are you trying to do something commercial with it?

ken


--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:=

>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> I am happy that you like my demo. This particular experi=
ment was set 
> up to answer some questions I had in mind. The first one is=
 obvious, 
> is there a geometric regularity in the predator/prey task that=
 
> HyperNEAT can possibly exploit. And there is. I can see some 
> meaning=
ful behaviors emerging with HyperNEAT as early as the 4th or 
> 5th generat=
ion. My next question was, what is the difference between 
> the indirect e=
ncoding and the direct encoding. Let me make it more 
> clear. In your expe=
riments in the robot duel domain, both robot NNs 
> are encoded directly an=
d complexifying. They elaborate on previous 
> strategies by incrementally =
adding more structure, right? 
> What about HyperNEAT, does it preserve the=
 same dynamics, where the 
> CPPNs complexify but the substrate is fixed? D=
oes it lead to endless 
> alteration of strategies instead of elaboration? =
I can predict that 
> HyperNEAT can discover some complex connectivity patt=
erns between 
> hidden nodes to develop some kind of "intelligent" behavior=
, but is 
> that limited? 
> Well this question is still not answered becau=
se, as you mentioned, 
> the predator/prey task is too easy to learn, thoug=
h there is room for 
> the predator and prey to learn tricks to fool each o=
ther. For example 
> the prey can learn to hide behind walls, etc. 
> Yes I=
 compared it to direct encoding NEAT and generally I can conclude 
> that H=
yperNEAT develops strategies faster. Especially in the case of 
> many many=
 inputs. Scaling works as well, but it is not perfect. 
> Let me tell you a=
bout the source code. Unfortunately the core NEAT 
> library I wrote and us=
e is locked under an NDA but it is equivalent to 
> the rtNEAT modification=
 I released with the NEVH project. The 
> visualization routines are basica=
lly the same there, there is nothing 
> new at all. But I can release the s=
ource code for the demos 
> themselves. Please ask me about any details, I =
will be happy to help 
> anyone. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter, thanks for this Hyp=
erNEAT coevolution demo.  I see some
> > interesting behaviors evolving, bu=
t I am curious about your own
> > conclusions?  What did you learn from thi=
s experiment?  Did you try
> > comparing it to regular NEAT in the same dom=
ain?  I am not sure
> > whether the difference would be great since I am no=
t sure if this 
> task
> > is sufficiently complex to exhibit a significant=
 difference between
> > the methods.  That is, there is probably only so go=
od that you can 
> get
> > before new skills stop really mattering in this =
domain.
> > 
> > By the way, do you plan releasing source code for your var=
ious
> > experiments and AI code?  It seems like you have a nice system set=
 
> up
> > and other people might like tinkering with it.  I especially lik=
e 
> the
> > real-time CPPN/substrate displays.
> > 
> > ken
> >
